posts.name:
Kenneth Gobble
Kenneth Gobble
posts.content:
Beyond Vanity Metrics: Building Value-Driven Sales Organizations

Last month's discussion on rethinking sales metrics generated significant dialogue around how traditional measurements can misalign incentives. Let's dive deeper into actionable changes.

The Cost of Vanity Metrics

Traditional sales metrics like pure quota attainment and deal volume paint an incomplete picture. While they create impressive dashboards, they often mask underlying issues in customer satisfaction and long-term revenue stability.

Research from the "Revenue Collective" shows organizations fixated on traditional quotas experience 2.1x higher customer churn compared to those prioritizing value-based metrics.

Three Essential Shifts:

Outcome-Based Measurement

Track post-sale customer success indicators like adoption rates, expansion revenue, and solution utilization. These metrics better reflect genuine business impact.

Quality Over Quantity

Monitor customer feedback scores, retention rates, and expansion opportunities. High-pressure tactics may close deals but damage long-term relationships.

Leading Indicators

Focus on pipeline health metrics that predict sustainable growth: engagement quality scores, solution fit ratings, and customer readiness assessments.

The Path Forward

Modern sales organizations are already seeing results. Companies emphasizing customer value metrics consistently outperform traditional quota-focused teams by 2.3x in two-year revenue growth.

The transition requires commitment from leadership and updated compensation structures. But the data is clear - aligning sales metrics with customer success drives sustainable growth.

What value-based metrics are you tracking? Share your experiences below.

comments.commentText: Vanity metrics sure are attractive...I struggle myself to really focus on the right KPIs to track week over week. For me (as of now at least), it's focused on the vital inputs that move the needle for metrics like quota attainment.
Michael P. Nobiletti quota attainment is one of many KPIs that need to be measure to really know the health of an organization. Thanks for commenting!
Really thoughtful post Kenneth! Focusing on metrics like retention and adoption rates has made a big difference in creating sustainable growth for my team.
Ryan Gleason that is great! I do not hate vanity metrics, but I feel they are too easily manipulated and deliver the wrong message to execs

posts.commentAdded: Great insights on shifting from vanity metrics to value-driven strategies! Emphasizing customer success is key to sustainable growth. What metrics have you seen work?

nick stagge ğŸ’­
nick stagge ğŸ’­
posts.content:
As an agency owner, I'm often asked why hire an agency over a freelancer, fractional CMO, or in-house marketer.

My answer may surprise you 

Thereâ€™s no one-size-fits-all solution. The truth is each option has value and validity. I'd exercise caution to anyone who tells you there's only one right decision â€” or someone who is quick to trash any of these options (they're looking out for themselves, not you).

The right choice depends on your goals, budget, and internal resources.


â€ Freelancer â€“ Best for specialized work & flexibility
 Cost-effective for project-based work
 Specialized expertise in a very specific area
 Flexible availability â€” hire when you need them. Pause when you don't
 Quick turnaround for short-term or urgent projects
 Brings fresh, outside perspectives to your business


 Agency â€“ Best for scalability & multi-channel execution
 Access to a full team of experts across strategy & execution
 Established processes for efficiency & performance tracking
 Scalable solutions â€” whether you need one service or full-funnel marketing
 Keeps up with industry trends, tools, and best practices
 Removes hiring/training burdens â€” just plug into their expertise


â€ In-House Marketer â€“ Best for long-term brand focus
 Deep understanding of your brand, audience, & business goals
 Seamless collaboration with internal teams
 Immediate availability for day-to-day needs & pivots
 Can align marketing with internal company culture & vision
 Long-term investment that builds institutional knowledge


 Fractional CMO â€“ Best for strategic leadership without full-time costs
 Executive-level leadership at a fraction of a full-time CMOâ€™s salary
 Builds & optimizes your marketing strategy for long-term growth
 Aligns marketing efforts with business objectives
 Provides mentorship & leadership to existing marketing teams
 Ideal for businesses not yet ready for a full-time marketing executive


 The best choice?
It depends on your stage of growth, budget, & internal resources. Many businesses benefit from a mix â€” leveraging an in-house marketer while working with freelancers or agencies for specialized needs, or bringing in a fractional CMO to set direction before hiring a full-time team.

No single option is inherently better â€” just different paths to the same goal: growing your business effectively.
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Choosing the right marketing support is crucial. A blend of options might just be the key to achieving your goals effectively!

posts.name:
Shelley Perry
Shelley Perry
posts.content:
Did you know that 80% of professionals say networking is crucial for career success, yet most of us only actively engage with less than 10% of our network? 

This is a problem space that I have been interested in for years.

I decided to learn by doing and I have been building an AI agent to act as my networking assistant to develop and maintain my professional network.

Here's what's fascinating â©

Instead of manually tracking hundreds of connections, I've been using AI to:
â€¢ Analyze communication patterns and suggest timely follow-ups
â€¢ Generate personalized conversation starters based on contacts' recent activities
â€¢ Find relevant information on a topic that will interest my network connections.

I am using this to replace what I have paid a virtual assistant to help with over the years, I had lots of requirements for my Agent (itâ€™s a work in progress).

The most surprising insight? AI doesn't make networking â€˜roboticâ€™ â€“ it makes it more human.

By handling the heavy lifting of relationship management, AI frees up mental space for genuine, meaningful interactions.

It does 80% of the lift and I spend the last 20% making it personal â€“ and I spend more of my networking time on the best f2f connections.

What's your take on using AI for relationship building?

Have you experimented with any AI tools to maintain your professional network?

I'd love to hear about it, please share below

comments.commentText: My concern would be that we become so accustomed to leveraging AI that perhaps at the start we personalize the message but at some point we just allow AI to do the whole thing. Before you know it our AI will be communicating with our networks AI and the actual people will have no idea they touched base

Mark Selinger while that may happen, I learned later in my career how important networking is, and I will not let it happen. my network is too important to me. I will continue to use the tools available to help and max the time for the personal / depth of connection. My network you can hold me accountable.

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! AI can enhance our networking efforts and allow for more authentic connections. Excited to see how it evolves in this space!

posts.content:
Why do things slow down as you scale?

At first, 

- Decisions are quick.
- Work gets done pretty fast.
- And communication is...simple.

Then growth happens.

More people.
Bigger teams.
And then suddenly,
everything slows down.

Youâ€™ve tried the usual fixes:

- Better tools.
- More processes.
- Endless documentation
- Even reorganizing your org chart.

But hereâ€™s the truth:
That's EXACTLY where you're making it harder.

Tomorrow, Iâ€™ll break it all down:

Why org charts fail.
What you should do, instead.

Scaling doesnâ€™t have to mean slowing down.
Rather, you can't afford to slow down.

Get the answers in my newsletter tomorrow.

Subscribe to CEO Mastery

comments.commentText:
Your speed and agility was your advantage. 
Now, you are adding complexities with tools and processes, slowing down delivery. 

This is such a critical challenge that I've created a 3-part series on scaling without sacrificing speed.

Part 1 drops tomorrow.

Subscribe now and learn how to maintain your speed while growing:
Subscribe here: https://surabhishenoy(dot)com/newsletter-subscribe/

To address the "slowness problem", I'm a big fan of self-organizing development teams (speaking of the IT world now). If you have a crystal clear vision (the WHY), the strategy to get there and the top-down communication is as transparent as possible, then the majority of decisions can be solved by the development teams without having to go up and down.

But those teams need to have all the information they need, all the time. Simply said, if you don't really need to, don't hide any information from the employees and they will become much faster in moving the needle forward.

Jan Suchan Agreed, but I have heard enough time "What, you are working on that too?"
And fighting for experts between teams is a common issue.

Surabhi Shenoy Yeah, the duplicity of work is very common. From my experience, it happens often in all the internal tools and systems.

One solution can be an internal open-source policy. If you build something useful, you treat it as an open-source project for the community. Only, in this case, the community is your company.

posts.commentAdded: Excited to see your insights! Scaling shouldnt slow us downâ€”looking forward to the solutions youll share in the newsletter! ğŸš€

posts.name:
Paul Roetzer
Paul Roetzer
posts.content:
Yesterday, OpenAI announced a $500 billion Stargate Project: "a new company which intends to invest $500 billion over the next four years building new AI infrastructure for OpenAI in the United States. We will begin deploying $100 billion immediately. This infrastructure will secure American leadership in AI, create hundreds of thousands of American jobs, and generate massive economic benefit for the entire world."

Given Elon Musk's relationship with the new administration (and notoriously acrimonious relationship with OpenAI and Sam Altman), it was interesting to note his absence from the press conference with Trump, and his lack of involvement in the first major AI initiative of the presidency.

I assumed it was only a matter of time until we heard Musk's thoughts on it. He delivered in a reply to the OpenAI Tweet: "They donâ€™t actually have the money"

To which Altman replied: "i genuinely respect your accomplishments and think you are the most inspiring entrepreneur of our time"

I thought, maybe for a moment, Altman was extending an olive branch for the good of America and the future of humanity. That lasted for about an hour.

In another reply to OpenAI, Musk said: "SoftBank has well under $10B secured. I have that on good authority."

To which Altman replied:

"wrong, as you surely know.

"want to come visit the first site already under way?

"this is great for the country. i realize what is great for the country isn't always what's optimal for your companies, but in your new role i hope you'll mostly put ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ first."

Who knows what happens next, but it will certainly be entertaining to watch how this all unfolds.

comments.commentText: More on the Stargate Project https://openai.com/index/announcing-the-stargate-project/

Break out the popcorn  I was thinking this very thing - how did that go over between Musk and the President? Will Elon having the President's ear impact any of this? And then I also wondered how did they get here without Sam and Elon having to be in the same "room" at some point?

posts.commentAdded: Fascinating dynamics between Altman and Musk! Excited to see how this unfolds and the impact on AI and the U.S. economy. #AILeadership

Unlike a lot of SaaS emails today, itâ€™s specific about how its offer solves the problem: that benchmarking is hard because GRC programs are so different from one another.

ï¸ LogicGate offers a solution in the form of results from surveying 350 industry insiders.

The bullet points do a great job of teasing the report and telling a story with data: many companies are overspending on GRC tools and increasing budgets â€” despite poor program performance.

And the CTA perfectly matches the subject line, ensuring subscribers arenâ€™t disappointed when they open the email. 

The only thing I would change? Iâ€™d make the subject line more specific by teasing one of the stats in the email. For example, â€œ[2024 survey] Why 21% of companies overspend on GRC.â€

ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚? ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—²ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¹?

comments.commentText: The point you made about the subject line is spot on. Adding that stat with a question evokes curiosity and makes it almost irresistible not to open. Curiosity is one of the most if not THE most, powerful forces in marketing.
Corey Koehler
Auroriele +1 on more detailed result + they might also want to add a preheader that builds on this. Maybe they did add it, not seeing it.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Leveraging unique data really captures attention. A compelling subject line can make all the difference too!
